paragraphs: Sign up (free) to receive the 5 Tactics in My Longevity Toolkit delivered by email as a 5-day course, my weekly newsletter, and new podcast announcements.
Learn how to live longer, be healthier, and optimize your performance.

The Drive is hosted by Dr. Peter Attia, a Stanford/Johns Hopkins/NIH-trained physician focusing on the applied science of longevity, the extension of human life, and well-being. With over 50 million episodes downloaded, it features topics including exercise, nutritional biochemistry, cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, mental health, and much more.
“Ask Me Anything” episodes
All podcast episodes
Also available on these platforms
“Your podcasts are like a massive gift to humanity. I’ve been enjoying them very much.”

“If you want to know how to live longer, and how to live better, you should be listening to Peter. His unique spectrum of experience, relentless obsession over details, and ability to translate the cutting edge of science into something the rest of us can use is invaluable.”
“I’ve always been fascinated with medicine. I really enjoy his take on things, his clarity, the brilliant guests he has on, and how out of my depth he is.”
Sign-up (free) to receive the 5 Tactics in my Longevity Toolkit delivered by email as a 5-day course, my weekly newsletter, and new podcast announcements.

#1 New York Times Bestseller
Available now everywhere books are sold

Wouldn’t you like to live longer? And better? In this operating manual for longevity, Dr. Peter Attia draws on the latest science to deliver innovative nutritional interventions, techniques for optimizing exercise and sleep, and tools for addressing emotional and mental health.

For all its successes, mainstream medicine has failed to make much progress against the diseases of aging that kill most people: heart disease, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and type 2 diabetes. Too often, it intervenes with treatments too late to help, prolonging lifespan at the expense of healthspan, or quality of life. Dr. Attia believes we must replace this outdated framework with a personalized, proactive strategy for longevity, one where we take action now, rather than waiting.
Introducing…
Take the health journey of a patient in Peter Attia’s medical practice with his one-of-a-kind digital program.
Exercise and physical health
Nutritional biochemistry
Sleep and longevity
Disease prevention
Mental and emotional health
View all topics

Peter Attia, MD, is the founder of Early Medical, a medical practice that applies the principles of Medicine 3.0 to patients with the goal of lengthening their lifespan and simultaneously improving their healthspan. He is the host of The Drive, one of the most popular podcasts covering the topics of health and medicine.

Dr. Attia received his medical degree from the Stanford University School of Medicine and trained for five years at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in general surgery, where he was the recipient of several prestigious awards, including resident of the year.  He spent two years at the National Institutes of Health as a surgical oncology fellow at the National Cancer Institute, where his research focused on immune-based therapies for melanoma.
He lives in Austin, Texas with his wife and three kids.
He is licensed in Texas (S8803), California (A96452), and New York (281406-1).
Cardiovascular disease risk and apoB
Replacing sugar with allulose
Does exercise affect lifespan?
Studying studies: relative risk vs. absolute risk
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.

title: Outlive: The Science & Art of Longevity - New Book by Peter Attia

h2: The Science & Art of Longevity
About the Authors
Order Now
Comment policy
h3: Rethinking Medicine to Live Better Longer
DON’T MISS YOUR CHANCE FOR A SIGNED BOOKPLATE COPY OF OUTLIVE

paragraphs: #1 New York Times Bestseller
AVAILABLE NOW
Available everywhere books are sold

A groundbreaking manifesto on living better and longer that challenges the conventional medical thinking on aging and reveals a new approach to preventing chronic disease and extending long-term health, from a visionary physician and leading longevity expert.
“One of the most important books you’ll ever read.”—Steven D. Levitt, New York Times bestselling author of Freakonomics

Wouldn’t you like to live longer? And better? In this operating manual for longevity, Dr. Peter Attia draws on the latest science to deliver innovative nutritional interventions, techniques for optimizing exercise and sleep, and tools for addressing emotional and mental health.

For all its successes, mainstream medicine has failed to make much progress against the diseases of aging that kill most people: heart disease, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and type 2 diabetes. Too often, it intervenes with treatments too late to help, prolonging lifespan at the expense of healthspan, or quality of life. Dr. Attia believes we must replace this outdated framework with a personalized, proactive strategy for longevity, one where we take action now, rather than waiting.
We have a limited number of signed copies of Outlive. Click the link below to order yours. Please note, they are only available to ship in the US.

Dr. Peter Attia is my doctor and also my friend. He is a specialist in longevity and someone I trust with my life. What separates him from others is his pursuit of quality of life from all angles—physical, emotional, mental, relational, and spiritual health. This incredible book is a call to action and a reminder to always participate and never be passive. It will arm you with the tools you need to live a long, meaningful, and fulfilling life.

Finally, there is a modern, thorough, clear, and actionable manual for how to maximize our immediate and long-term health. Firmly grounded in data and real-life conditions, Outlive makes obvious which actions we all need to take and, just as important, what we all need to pay attention to in order to live a long, vital life. As the most accurate and comprehensive health guide published to date, Outlive is not just informative, it is important.

In Outlive, Peter Attia has delivered the definitive look at the complex subject of longevity. Comprehensive and rigorous, Outlive is full of surprising insights into the diseases of aging that will likely kill most of us, and the tactics and techniques that can help us live longer and in better health. Attia’s writing surprises and delights us, while provoking a new way to think about longevity.
Outlive a well-founded strategic and tactical approach to extending lifespan while also improving our physical, cognitive, and emotional health.

Dr. Attia’s aim is less to tell you what to do and more to help you learn how to think about long-term health, in order to create the best plan for you as an individual. In Outlive, readers will discover:

Aging and longevity are far more malleable than we think; our fate is not set in stone. With the right roadmap, you can plot a different path for your life, one that lets you outlive your genes to make each decade better than the one before.

Peter Attia, MD, is the founder of Early Medical. He received his medical degree from the Stanford University School of Medicine and trained at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in general surgery. He also trained at the NIH as a surgical oncology fellow at the National Cancer Institute, where his research focused on immune-based therapies for melanoma. He serves on the editorial board for the journal Aging. He is the host of The Drive, one of the most popular podcasts covering the topics of health, medicine, and longevity.

Bill Gifford is a veteran journalist and author of the New York Times bestseller Spring Chicken: Stay Young Forever (Or Die Trying). His work has appeared in Outside, Scientific American, Bloomberg Businessweek, Men’s Health, and numerous other publications.

Outlive completely transformed my approach to growing old. Peter Attia is among the most brilliant people I’ve ever met, and he’s succeeded in packing a life’s worth of insights into this book. It promises to be one of the most important books you’ll ever read.
In Outlive, Peter Attia explores the science of not just prolonging life, but also prolonging aliveness. Attia makes the crucial connection between overall health and relational health.
Available everywhere books are sold
Looking to Purchase internationally?
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.
Δ

Peter

title: The Peter Attia Drive Podcast - Peter Attia

h2: Featured Podcasts
#85 – Iñigo San Millán, Ph.D.: Zone 2 Training and Metabolic Health
#47 – Matthew Walker, Ph.D., on sleep – Part I of III: Dangers of poor sleep, Alzheimer’s risk, mental health, memory consolidation, and more
#87 – Rick Johnson, M.D.: Metabolic Effects of Fructose
#202 – Peter on nutrition, disease prevention, sleep, and more — looking back on the last 100 episodes
Recent Podcasts
#321 – Dopamine and addiction: navigating pleasure, pain, and the path to recovery | Anna Lembke, M.D.
#320 – AMA 64: New insights on GLP-1 agonists (Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro) – efficacy, benefits, risks, and considerations in the rapidly evolving weight-loss drug landscape

title: Podcast Archives - Peter Attia

h2: #321 – Dopamine and addiction: navigating pleasure, pain, and the path to recovery | Anna Lembke, M.D.
#320 – AMA 64: New insights on GLP-1 agonists (Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro) – efficacy, benefits, risks, and considerations in the rapidly evolving weight-loss drug landscape
#319 ‒ Peter’s key takeaways on liver health, heart rate variability, AI in medicine, klotho, and lactate metabolism | Quarterly Podcast Summary #2
#318 ‒ Cycling phenom and Tour de France champion Tadej Pogačar reveals his training strategies, on-bike nutrition, and future aspirations
#317 ‒ Reforming medicine: uncovering blind spots, challenging the norm, and embracing innovation | Marty Makary, M.D., M.P.H.
#316 – AMA #63: A guide for hair loss: causes, treatments, transplants, and sex-specific considerations
#315 ‒ Life after near-death: a new perspective on living, dying, and the afterlife | Sebastian Junger
#314 ‒ Rethinking nutrition science: the evolving landscape of obesity treatment, GLP-1 agonists, protein, and the need for higher research standards | David Allison, Ph.D.
#313 – AMA #62: Protein’s impact on appetite and weight management, and uric acid’s link to disease and how to manage levels
#312 – A masterclass in lactate: Its critical role as metabolic fuel, implications for diseases, and therapeutic potential from cancer to brain health and beyond | George A. Brooks, Ph.D.
Comment policy

paragraphs: Want to view all past podcasts on a single page? View our podcast archive.

“When we do things intentionally that are physically or mentally challenging for us, our body senses injury and up regulates feel good neurotransmitters. . .so we get our dopamine indirectly by paying for it upfront.” —Anna Lembke

“If you’re taking these drugs, really, really pay attention to your protein consumption and your resistance training. . .that’s obviously going to be an important part of being on the right side of that body composition curve.” — Peter Attia
“In humans, klotho is indeed a longevity gene. More klotho from the gene means longer life, better cognition. Take it away, shorter life, worse cognition.” —Peter Attia
“You see all these three things—the speed, heart rate, and power. Then you see how you feel and which zone are you really in.” —Tadej Pogačar
“One of the most important qualities of a physician is humility, knowing your limits, and having the self-awareness that you could be wrong.” —Marty Makary
“Genetic sensitivity to DHT appears far more important than absolute DHT level. But. . .lowering DHT is a very important strategy to either preventing or halting hair loss.” —Peter Attia
“I was allowed to go to the precipice, look over the edge, and then allowed to come back.” —Sebastian Junger
“I think we really need a radically different public health paradigm.” —David Allison
“The body responds in pretty significant ways to alterations in protein availability.” —Peter Attia
“Lactate is not just an innocent bystander. It’s a participant in the process of powering muscle, in fact, all cells.” —George Brooks
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.
Δ
Content
Peter

title: Ask Me Anything (AMA) Episodes - Peter Attia

h1: #320 – AMA 64: New insights on GLP-1 agonists (Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro) – efficacy, benefits, risks, and considerations in the rapidly evolving weight-loss drug landscape
#316 – AMA #63: A guide for hair loss: causes, treatments, transplants, and sex-specific considerations
h2: #301 – AMA #59: Inflammation: its impact on aging and disease risk, and how to identify, prevent, and reduce it
#297 – AMA #58: Iron: its role in health, testing methods, and strategies for preventing and managing iron deficiency
#293 – AMA #57: High-intensity interval training: benefits, risks, protocols, and impact on longevity
#289 – AMA #56: Cancer screening: pros and cons, screening options, interpreting results, and more
#285 – AMA #55: Exercise: longevity-focused training, goal setting, improving deficiencies, managing emotional stress, and more
#282 – AMA #54: Magnesium: risks of deficiency, how to correct it, supplement options, potential cognitive and sleep benefits, and more
#279 – AMA #53: Metabolic health & pharmacologic interventions: SGLT-2 inhibitors, metformin, GLP-1 agonists, and the impact of statins
#275 – AMA #52: Hormone replacement therapy: practical applications and the role of compounding pharmacies
#271 – AMA #51: Understanding and improving your metabolic health
#266 – AMA #50: Genetics: how they impact disease risk, what you can do about it, testing, and more
#262 – AMA #49: Heart rate recovery, strength training, rucking, kidney function, and brain health
#258 – AMA #48: Blood pressure—how to measure, manage, and treat high blood pressure
#254 – AMA #47: Cold therapy: pros, cons, and its impact on longevity
#251 – AMA #46: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer’s disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more
#246 – AMA #45: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
#242 – AMA #44: Peter’s historical changes in body composition with his evolving dietary, fasting, and training protocols
#238 – AMA #43: Understanding apoB, LDL-C, Lp(a), and insulin as risk factors for cardiovascular disease
#233 – AMA #42: Optimizing sleep – bedtime routine, molecule regimen, sleep trackers, sauna, & more
#231 – AMA #41: Medicine 3.0, developments in the field of aging, healthy habits in times of stress, and more
#227 – AMA #40: Body composition, protein, time-restricted feeding, fasting, DEXA scans, and more
#223 – AMA #39: The Centenarian Decathlon, zone 2, VO2 max, and more
#218 – AMA #38: Can you exercise too much?
#214 – AMA #37: Bone health—everything you need to know
#211 – AMA #36: Fruits & vegetables—everything you need to know
#207 – AMA #35: “Anti-Aging” Drugs — NAD+, metformin, & rapamycin
#203 – AMA #34: What Causes Heart Disease?
#200 – AMA #33: Hydration—electrolytes, supplements, sports drinks, performance effects, and more
#196 – AMA #32: Exercise, squats, deadlifts, BFR, and TRT
#193 – AMA #31: Heart rate variability (HRV), alcohol, sleep, and more
#188 – AMA #30: How to Read and Understand Scientific Studies
#184 – AMA #29: GLP-1 Agonists – The Future of Treating Obesity?
#180 – AMA #28: All things testosterone and testosterone replacement therapy
#176 – AMA #27: The importance of muscle mass, strength, and cardiorespiratory fitness for longevity
#173 – AMA #26: Continuous glucose monitors, zone 2 training, and a framework for interventions
#170 – AMA #25: Navigating the complexities and nuances of cancer screening
#165 – AMA #24: Deep dive into blood glucose: why it matters, important metrics to track, and superior insights from a CGM
#161 – AMA #23: All Things Nicotine: deep dive into its cognitive and physical benefits, risks, and mechanisms of action
#157 – AMA #22: Losing fat and gaining fat: the lessons of fat flux
#153 – AMA #21: Deep dive into olive oil, high-intensity exercise, book update, and more
#149 – AMA #20: Simplifying the complexities of insulin resistance: how it’s measured, how it manifests in the muscle and liver, and what we can do about it
#145 – AMA #19: Deep dive on Zone 2 training, magnesium supplementation, and how to engage with your doctor
#141 – AMA #18: Deep dive: sugar and sugar substitutes
#136 – AMA #17: Body composition methods tour de force, insulin resistance, and Topo Chico
#132 – AMA #16: Exploring hot and cold therapy
#127 – AMA #3 with sleep expert, Matthew Walker, Ph.D.: Fasting, gut health, blue light, caffeine, REM sleep, and more
#124 – AMA #15: Real-world case studies—metabolic dysregulation, low testosterone, menopause, and more
AMA with Dom D’Agostino, Ph.D., Part II of II: Ketosis for cancer and chronic disease, hyperbaric oxygen therapy, and the effect of ketosis on female health

AMA #12: Strategies for longevity (which don’t require a doctor)
AMA #11: All things fasting
AMA #10: Low testosterone, hypothyroidism, building muscle (and preserving it while fasting)
Celebrity AMA with Apolo Ohno and Sasha Cohen: Fasting, rapamycin, performance vs. longevity, and more
AMA #9: NAD & metformin, fat-burning zone, creatine, estrogenization of men, emergency kit for cold & flu, and more
AMA #8: DNA tests, longevity genes, metformin, fasting markers, salt, inflammation, and more
AMA #7: Exercise framework, deadlifting, lower back pain, blood pressure, nootropics, CGM, and more
AMA #2 with sleep expert, Matthew Walker, Ph.D.: short sleep mutants, optimal sleep environment, sleep apnea, & rapid fire questions
AMA with sleep expert, Matthew Walker, Ph.D.: Strategies for sleeping more, sleeping better, and avoiding things that are disrupting sleep
AMA #6: Fasting framework, vitamin supplementation, antioxidants, time management, problem-solving, and more
AMA #5: calcium scores, Centenarian Decathlon, exercise, muscle glycogen, keto, and more
AMA #4: sleep, jet lag protocol, autophagy, metformin, and more
AMA #3: supplements, women’s health, patient care, and more
AMA #2: the Nothingburger — results from Peter’s week-long fast between two weeks of nutritional ketosis — and answering questions on all things fasting
AMA #1: alcohol, best lab tests, wearables, finding the right doc, racing, and more
Comment policy

paragraphs: Our Ask Me Anything (AMA) podcast episodes are released monthly and are exclusively available to our premium members. If you are not a member, you can subscribe today to get immediate access to our full back catalog of AMAs, plus future AMA episodes. You’ll also get the ability to participate by submitting your questions via the AMA page for possible future episodes, plus other exclusive benefits.
#313 – AMA #62: Protein’s impact on appetite and weight management, and uric acid’s link to disease and how to manage levels
#308 – AMA #61: Sun exposure, sunscreen, and skin health: relationship between sun exposure and skin cancer, vitamin D production, and photoaging, how to choose a sunscreen, and more
#306 – AMA #60: preventing cognitive decline, nutrition myths, lowering blood glucose, apoB, and blood pressure, and more
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.

title: The Qualys Podcast - Peter Attia

h2: Featured Qualys
How Alzheimer's disease is diagnosed
My thoughts on alcohol consumption and health
The 5 habits Tim Ferriss returns to most reliably
The difference between glucose and fructose
Comment policy
h3: In addition to The Qualys, subscribers also receive additional benefits:

paragraphs: The Qualys is a subscriber-exclusive podcast, released Tuesday through Friday, and published exclusively on our private, subscriber-only podcast feed. Qualys is short-hand for “qualifying round,” which  are typically the fastest laps driven in a race car—done  before the race to determine starting position on the grid for race day. The Qualys are short (i.e., “fast”), typically less than ten minutes, and highlight the best questions, topics, and tactics discussed on The Drive.
Subscribe to the Qualys
A short intro from Peter about The Qualys
#18 – Richard Isaacson, M.D.: Alzheimer’s prevention
#04 – AMA #1: alcohol, best lab tests, wearables, finding the right doc, racing, and more
#01 – Tim Ferriss: depression, psychedelics, and emotional resilience
#14 – Robert Lustig, M.D., M.S.L.: fructose, processed food, NAFLD, and changing the food system
Listen to more Qualys

Access to members-only Ask Me Anything (AMA) podcasts and AMA forum
                        You get access to the back catalogue of AMA podcasts, and all future AMA episodes. You’ll also get the ability to participate by submitting your questions via the AMA page for possible future episodes. Full AMA episodes will be released through the members-only podcast feed.

Comprehensive podcast show notes 
                        We take extreme pride in detailing every topic, paper, person, and thing discussed in every episode of The Drive. This takes us a lot of time to produce, but there truly is no better way to take a deep dive into any of the topics we explore on the show.

Exclusive discount codes for products we believe in 
                        I want my supporters to get the best deals out there on products I love. Although we do not take sponsorship money from anyone, we’re working closely with some products I love and buy myself to get exclusive members-only discounts. This allows us to take the money sponsors would have paid me, and pass that on as savings to you instead.

Exclusive private podcast feed 
              Subscribe to our members-only podcast feed in your favorite podcast player to get every episode of The Drive without the subscriber callout, plus full episodes of our monthly, members-only AMA podcasts, and other exclusive content.
Subscribe Now
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.

title: Premium Articles Archives - Peter Attia

h2: Cold therapy: the facts, the myths, and the how-to
A guide to Zone 2 training: its profound impact on health, detailed training instructions, addressing male and female differences, and more
Assessing metabolic health: where HbA1c falls short, and how it compares to fasting glucose, CGM, and OGTT
Do high protein diets increase cancer risk?
Body composition: impact on disease risk and how to assess and improve it
The [almost] unbelievable effects of a high maximal aerobic capacity on all-cause mortality
Optimizing protein quantity, distribution, and quality
Saunas: the facts, the myths, and the how-to
Is low-to-moderate alcohol consumption beneficial for longevity?
“Biological” clocks: a peek into the future or a haphazard guess of mortality?
Comment policy
h3: Sign up to receive the 5 tactics in my Longevity Toolkit, followed by non-lame, weekly emails on the latest strategies and tactics for increasing your lifespan, healthspan, and well-being (plus new podcast announcements).

paragraphs: These articles are produced by Peter and our dedicated team of research analysts, and cover a wide range of longevity-related topics in much greater detail than those we send in our free weekly newsletter. Peter and our research team work hard to make these articles topical, exhaustive, interesting, and, whenever possible, actionable.
Forms of cold therapy have been used for generations for a number of alleged health benefits, but which are supported by evidence?

Zone 2 training is critical for improving and maintaining mitochondrial health and aerobic capacity, so we’ve put together a resource to answer all of your questions about this pillar of exercise and how to get the most out of Zone 2 training.
Exclusive reliance on HbA1c and other static metrics may miss the opportunity for early intervention
Is there any merit to the idea that consuming more protein increases one’s risk of developing or dying from cancer?
A refresher on why you should care about body composition and a practical guide to determining and interpreting your measurements
Everything you need to know about VO2 max
Δ
Maximizing muscle protein synthesis is more than a matter of daily protein intake. How we distribute protein throughout the day matters, as does protein quality.
Sauna use appears to be genuinely beneficial, but not all claims stand up to scrutiny
There is a common belief that low-to-moderate consumption of alcohol has unique health benefits. What does the evidence show?
Potential uses for the epigenetics of aging and why I don’t put much stock in epigenetics-based aging clocks at present
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.
Δ

Peter

title: Topics - Peter Attia

h2: Diseases & Conditions: Prevention tactics, treatments, and more
Longevity Toolkit
Extending Lifespan (Length of Life)
Improving Healthspan (Quality of Life)
Other Popular Topics
Comment policy

paragraphs: This website, my podcast, and my weekly email newsletter all focus on translating the science of longevity into something accessible, digestible, and actionable for everyone.
To learn more about my framework for longevity, and the 5 tactics in my Longevity Toolkit, sign up for my free email newsletter. You can also watch the video on my start here page.

Over 80% of deaths in people over 50 who do not smoke can be grouped into 4 main categories, what I like to call the four horsemen of chronic disease. If you want to live longer, delaying the onset of these chronic diseases is critical.
We have five main tactics at our disposal to affect our longevity. To dive deeper into each of these domains, sign up for my free email newsletter or click on the categories below.

One of the foundational concepts of longevity is that if you want to live longer, you have to live longer without chronic disease, not live longer with chronic disease. This knowledge, combined with one’s family medical history and individual labs can then help focus attention on the specific chronic disease(s) you are most at risk of developing.

More often than not, people care less about how long they live (lifespan) and more about how well they live (healthspan). Healthspan has 3 main components: cognitive health, physical health, and emotional health.
For a full, complete list of topics, click here to view our tag index.
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.
Δ
Content
Peter
Connect

title: Exercising for Longevity | Peter Attia, M.D.

h2: Peter Attia on Zone 2 and Zone 5 Training
Research Worth Sharing, October 2024 Edition
High-intensity interval training and cognitive function in older adults: promising but limited findings
#318 ‒ Cycling phenom and Tour de France champion Tadej Pogačar reveals his training strategies, on-bike nutrition, and future aspirations
Could plasma protein levels be a surrogate for VO2 max testing as a measure of cardiorespiratory fitness?
Is zone 5 training okay to do immediately following zone 2 training?
A study suggesting that exercise does not impact mortality offers little more than click-bait
A guide to Zone 2 training: its profound impact on health, detailed training instructions, addressing male and female differences, and more
#313 – AMA #62: Protein’s impact on appetite and weight management, and uric acid’s link to disease and how to manage levels
#312 – A masterclass in lactate: Its critical role as metabolic fuel, implications for diseases, and therapeutic potential from cancer to brain health and beyond | George A. Brooks, Ph.D.
Oldies-But-Goodies, August 2024 Edition
Comment policy
h3: Sign up to receive the 5 tactics in my Longevity Toolkit, followed by non-lame, weekly emails on the latest strategies and tactics for increasing your lifespan, healthspan, and well-being (plus new podcast announcements).

paragraphs: Exercise might be the most potent “drug” we have for extending the quality and perhaps quantity of our years of life. My framework for exercise is built upon four pillars: stability (the foundation), strength, aerobic / zone 2 training, & anaerobic / zone 5 training.
Below is a compilation of clips, articles, and podcast focused on exercising through the lens of longevity, and how to train for, what I like to call, the “Centenarian Olympics.”
This audio clip was pulled from “Ask Me Anything” episode #12 — Strategies for longevity (which don’t require a doctor). This…
Using biofeedback to reach weight loss goals, preventing falls with exercise, the impact of social support on stress eating, and an atlas of data on changes related to muscle aging
A new study indicates that HIIT may help delay or even reverse age-related declines in memory and learning, but this exercise modality remains just one aspect of a well-balanced regimen.
“You see all these three things—the speed, heart rate, and power. Then you see how you feel and which zone are you really in.” —Tadej Pogačar
A proteomics model may provide an alternative method for estimating risk of mortality and chronic disease
This video clip is from #201 – Deep dive back into Zone 2 with Iñigo San-Millán, Ph.D., originally released on…
Challenges to long-held knowledge makes for attention-grabbing headlines, but not necessarily good science. Excuse me while I scream.
Δ

Zone 2 training is critical for improving and maintaining mitochondrial health and aerobic capacity, so we’ve put together a resource to answer all of your questions about this pillar of exercise and how to get the most out of Zone 2 training.
“The body responds in pretty significant ways to alterations in protein availability.” —Peter Attia
“Lactate is not just an innocent bystander. It’s a participant in the process of powering muscle, in fact, all cells.” —George Brooks

A collection of past newsletters on topics including the influence of bias versus noise, problems with vitamin D literature, muscle mass and cognition, the effects of late-night snacking, and a case study in cardiovascular health
Peter Attia is a physician focusing on the applied science of longevity.
Δ
Content
Peter
Connect
